11:14 am
BE11:14am

Here's what it means.

BE11:14am

We estimate the incremental tariff (15%) on $200bn of trade would reduce China’s exports by 2.7% and drag down China’s GDP growth by another 50bps, and remove another 2.1m jobs in China in the medium term – Together with the previous two rounds of tariffs, the 25% tariff on a total of $250bn-worth of Chinese exports is estimated to reduce China’s exports by 5.6%, GDP growth by 1 ppt, and employment by 4.4m. But it will also hurt US inflation and US MNC’s interest in China. Given the supply chains can’t move out China quickly, the 15% additional tariff imposition, together with existing tariffs, could potentially affect China’s growth negatively by up to 0.5 ppt this year.

Izabella Kaminska I think that pic of Bryce's keyboard is a hatecrime against my appetite.
BE11:14am

This is via Citi.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Specifically, we expect the resumption of a tariff war will drag down the 2H GDP growth modestly by 0.25 ppt, if trade talks were to break down altogether – We expect a speedy reaction by China’s policy makers, with policy implementation made more effective. On the monetary policy front, the RRR could be further lowered, and more aggressive easing such as interest rate cuts could also be expected, if necessary. On the fiscal policy front, it is likely that the authorities revert to more infrastructure investment in 2H. Moreover, the gov’t could even issue more targeted measures to mitigate the impact from tariffs and boost sentiment for the private sector. Given the scope for fiscal and monetary stimulus is large in the near term, we believe the negative impact from additional tariffs will likely be managed better this time.

VV75 @Izabella, yeah I'm not going to get a croissant later anymore
Tom Dalgleish there's something churlish about BE
wayneJ Please tell us you are all getting new keyboards when u move?
BE11:15am

The resumption of trade war concerns will weigh on the RMB and capital outflow outlook – Further escalation of a trade war could push USDCNY towards 7 again, and we would also expect more interventions around 7, as CNYUSD at 7 is still an important psychological level for the PBoC to defend. China could tighten capital controls as well.
 If the trade conflict escalated further, tariffs on the remaining $325bn worth of Chinese goods could also be implemented in the foreseeable future – We expect both China and the US will still look to resume trade talks before the tariffs are actually implemented, as the uncertainty effect from the additional tariffs starts weighing on the world’s two largest economies, but also on the global economy. We thus are still cautiously optimistic a trade deal could eventually be signed.

11:17 am

JP11:17am

I am pretty shattered this morning. I attended a fascinating DB macro dinner with 30 clients last night and got home late. This was sandwiched around three successive sleep deprived nights. Night one the adrenaline was flowing because of Liverpool and I couldn’t get to sleep. Night two saw the new burglar alarm system go off twice and disturbed the whole house for well over an hour. However last night will take some beating. At 2ammy wife wakes me to say she’s heard a loud bang downstairs. I grumpily wake up and say the alarm hasn’t gone off and go back to sleep. She then looks out the bedroom door and says the hallway lights downstairs [which are on motion sensors] are on. Someone must have triggered them off. I’m still not convinced but she forces me out of bed. We creep downstairs and start to hear noises coming from the living room. At this point I’m a bit scared. We get to the hall and the noises are getting louder. My wife dials 999 and I grab the nearest blunt weapon (my golf driver). She keeps the 999 operator on the phone and says we’re going to go into the room with the intruder. We go in the room and the loud rustling noises suddenly stop. We’re very scared and creep around the room. On the floor behind the sofa we find a half unwrapped Easter Egg [still in wrapping paper] with teeth marks in it and our new radiator cover collapsed on the wooden floor [the apparent source of the bang]. At this point Bronte has decided to rescue us (she sleeps upstairs with us so it wasn’t her) and starts to poke her nose down a hole where the radiator work has been done. She is very excited. From all this we concluded that we have a huge rat that escaped from the hole in the floor where the radiators are, knocked off the cover, roamed around the ground floor, took an unused Easter egg from the kitchen, set off the motion light sensors and then started unwrapping it and nibbling it back in the living room. My wife then apologises to the 999 operator and luckily she laughs it off. 90 minutes later I finally manage to calm down enough to go to sleep. It was genuinely quite scary at one point.

PBateman quite dry in places but interesting eh
JP11:17am

That's Jim Reid at DB...and then...

MnM ay op!

11:18 am
JP11:18am

So the alarm this morning was as welcome as tariffs to financial markets. Indeed as we type this, the latest round of US tariffs on $200bn of Chinese exports has just come into place, taking the rate from 10% to 25%. Ahead of this equity markets fell across the globe yesterday, but they did rally off their lows during the afternoon in New York. Investors seemingly continue to try to cling to hope that policymakers on both sides opt to deescalate. The S&P 500 was down -1.49% just before the European close, but it bounced over a percent into the close after President Trump told reporters that a “deal is still possible,” and that he had received a “beautiful letter” from President Xi, and he may have a call with his Chinese counterpart soon. All in all this beautiful letter was worth $372 billion to US stocks [using Wiltshire 5000] from the lows. Most of my letters at the moment are bills so I would love that letter!! Anyway, high-level talks could keep a deal alive but Trump also said that “tariffs are very powerful” and that if he ends up raising them further, that would be “an excellent” alternative to a deal. In the meantime, Bloomberg is reporting that yesterday’s talks yielded little to no progress [citing sources]. So uncertainty is clearly elevated moving forward. So far there has been no news of any retaliation from China as we go to print. China’s ministry of commerce has said though that it “deeply regrets” the US tariff hike and says that it is forced to retaliate. One source of a potential retaliation announcement or hints could be the Foreign Ministry’s usual afternoon press conference [08:00am London Time]. Yesterday, China’s Commerce Ministry spokesman Gao had said to watch the Ministry of Commerce website for retaliation details. So one to keep an eye on.

PBateman talk about easy work
JP11:19am

So recapping the moves yesterday, starting with equities, the S&P 500 ended -0.31% yesterday, substantially above its -1.49% lows. The NASDAQ fell -0.41% [-1.85% at the lows] and DOW retreated -0.54% [-1.73% at the lows]. Continuing the trend of the week, tech and materials bore the brunt of the pain. In Europe, the STOXX 600 closed near its lows at -1.65% and DAX -1.69% with losses accelerating after the US walked in. This morning in Asia markets are trading mixed with the Shanghai Comp being up +1.50% which puts the move this week back to -5.99% but the worst week since October last year as we get into the final session. Other markets in China are also up with the CSI +1.86% (-6.30% on week) and Shenzhen Comp +1.82% (-6.01%). Bloomberg is reporting though that this week has seen China "national team" of state-linked buyers being active. Elsewhere the Nikkei is down -0.37% [-4.59%] and the Hang Seng is up +0.64% [-5.28%]. For completeness EM equities got hit to the tune of -1.58% yesterday, down -5.63% on the week.

BE11:21am

In our view, the key questions are: whether the two sides can stay engaged; how quickly they can reach an agreement; and what sort of deal is even possible at this point.
Best case scenario – getting back to a week ago
We think the best case scenario would be reaching an agreement similar to the one that appeared to be almost finished before last weekend. It might be possible for the US and China to get negotiations back on track relatively quickly and make an agreement. We still believe both sides want to find a way to keep the US-China economic relationship open, if for no other reason than to contain the economic and financial market fallout.
This will likely take time, however. Reaching an agreement will require concessions, probably from both sides. Those concessions will be politically costly, particularly if they come quickly. As a result, negotiations even just to get back to the status quo ante, will likely take time. Of course both sides have to keep talking. It will be important to see if the US and China can remain engaged even as they impose new barriers to trade. An early indicator of this will be what happens to the trade negotiation and whether they extend into this weekend. Both sides also have to signal that they are willing to quickly reverse the actions that they have just taken.

BE11:21am

Intermediate scenario – delayed negotiations lead to different deal
The breakdown that led to today’s actions may reflect a wider gap between the two sides than was evident before. In this case, negotiators may have to throw out much of their previous work. It is also possible that the political fallout from the actions taken today will force the US, China or both to step back from further negotiations for a time. Such a delay would increase uncertainty with negative consequences for both economies and financial markets.
It is also possible that this case could produce a deal that is narrower in scope that what had seemed to be on the table, possibly making it easier to achieve but with fewer benefits. It is also possible that a restart to negotiations could lead to an agreement that is broader in scope with more benefits. That would likely take more time, however, and the potential benefits of widening the negotiations would likely not be evident for some time.
Worst case scenario – protracted breakdown in negotiations
As noted above, the breakdown that occurred over the last week may reflect a wider gap between the two sides than was evident before. One possibility is that this break reflects a broad-based shift across the US government to seeing China as a strategic competitor that needs to be confronted more forcefully. Moreover, the escalation of the dispute may generate its own political dynamics that make it difficult for the two sides to continue negotiations.
In this case, effective negotiations may break down more or less permanently. Both sides have previously said they are prepared to accept the economic consequences of such a breach.

PBateman kept juncker away from the cameras... hehe
11:21 am
BE11:21am

How things could evolve from here
The next steps will depend on how governments, financial markets and the broader economy respond, as well as the domestic political reaction in each country. We will be watching all of these things. It will also be important to gauge what the break in the US-China trade negotiations means for US attitudes towards other key trade issues including the 18 May deadline for Section 232 auto tariffs and the ongoing effort to obtain Congressional ratification of the USMCA this year.
Finally, even if negotiations get back on track relatively quickly, it seems likely that the events of the last week have more or less permanently increased uncertainty. This is likely to have a long-lasting effect on financial markets, business confidence and investment.

BE11:36am

We estimate that as online sales penetration increases from current levels of 14% to 50% online, 19% less retail space will be needed, which on our estimates could rebase rents down 29% and reduce asset values by -50%. The shift to online is not a choice but a response to consumers using online retail as the most cost-effective way of maximizing ‘leisure time’ and minimizing ‘unpaid work’ The flip side is that we estimate a need for at least 38% more logistics space.

chad_john Tate is looking very interesting

BE11:37am

JP11:37am

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Shift to online reaching 50% could see rents decline 29% — We have analyzed a number of retailers and prime shopping centres and conclude that as retail sales shift towards 50% online, we estimate 29% rent declines would be required if retailers seek to maintain their current margins to investors and can’t meaningfully cut other costs.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

50% could come off asset values – A 29% decline in rents equates to a ten-year annual growth rate of net rental income of -3.4%. On a very prime portfolio changing this valuation assumption only would reduce shopping centre values by 50%.

Pharma @JP I'd hesitate to buy a smoke alarm online. It's something that you want to work reliably, and not worth risking getting a fake.
Kiwi-juice OK so nothing new from Citigroup. I wonder how long the Zalando and Co shows can continue, this is based on deals with corner shops to take the packages back and these shops did not foresee the amount of work it represents. So I would imagine that returns will start costing more for these firms soon
BE11:39am

Online can add 15% to 20% to leisure time, so there is no end in sight to online penetration - We estimate that using online shopping can save time that equates to adding 15-20% to weekend leisure time and 66% to 95% to weekday leisure time in the UK and France. In our view this likely ensures online retail will only accelerate as technology makes online retail ultimately accessible to the entire population and enables faster and cheaper delivery.

wayneJ Isn't the real issue rateable values and rents?
BE11:39am

First stage negative, but long-term impacts should be positive — Technological change (outlined in this note) is likely to provide the catalysts to facilitate consumers' desire for higher online spend. Citi estimates that automating ecommerce could automate 63% of jobs in sales and 80% in transport, warehousing and logistics. Robo taxi and delivery are in the early stages of commercialization and the removal of human costs could reduce ride prices by 40% (similar for deliveries). Beyond this, impacts have the potential for retailers to reduce their biggest cost, headcount, possibly taking the pressure off rents. Consumers' time and money saving could benefit shopping centres (e.g. UK vehicle costs are 296% of the average consumer's weekly spend on clothing and footwear).

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Shorter-term risks are rising – If NOI growth slows (as this note outlines is most likely and in our estimates), asset values are likely to fall, driving higher LTV, forcing increased and dilutive asset sales (for some raising the potential of dilutive equity), lower dividend cover and increased cost of keeping shopping centres relevant and investible. We reiterate our Sell on Hammerson, Intu, Klepierre, and Carmila, and we downgrade URW to Sell in a separate note

BE11:40am

Here's Unibail itself.

BE11:40am

Although URW has best-in-class
European NOI growth of 4-5%, the growth rate has been slowing since 2007 and a larger portion of growth is in ‘other’ income, which we believe is shorter-dated. We
also believe that portfolio values are at higher risk of decline than in 2008/09 as our estimates indicate that a 13% value decline could be driven if the exit yield increases 100bps or the growth rate of NOI assumed slows from 3.7% to 2.5%.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Price target declines 12%, estimating -15% price downside — The stock has rallied around 10% year to date and combined with incorporating the reduction in EPS guidance and dividend cover, our new price target implies 15% price downside and an -8% estimated total return.

The real questions, long term, it strikes us, revolve around barriers to entry and profitability. The assumption with many of these type of platform companies is that being global Number one can drive scale and this in turn creates massive barriers to entry and leads to long-term profitability. Therefore short term losses do not matter since in the long term they will be overcome and become insignificant in the grand scheme of things as the company achieves global domination. All roads lead to Amazon/Facebook, kind of thing. It may well be in the short term that this is the impression investors get, i.e. that Uber will end up being the clear winner, and it the stock may therefore even “prosper” in the short-term as investors ignore the bad news and focus instead on the 10-year picture, or at least what they hope the 10-year picture will be.

The issue with ride-hailing is that there are several “pinch points” which mean that the sailing medium/long term may not be quite as straightforward as in certain other industries with winner-takes-all economics. In fact, it seems likely that it will NOT end up being a winner-takes-all industry actually. It is already showing signs of fragmentation, less than 10 years after Uber began (in 2009). There are numerous other companies with significant share. See chart below. Note that this only includes the Number one in each country, if we included the Top 5 per country it would be a veritable rainbow and probably illegible.

JP11:53am

The success or otherwise of an investment is often mainly determined by the entry price of course and in this respect at least, Uber may have one thing going for it. Talk of $140-$150B at IPO was replaced by talk of $120B, which has in turn been replaced by talk of $80-$90B. What can we compare this to? We need to overlook the $3B of losses and instead compare it to $11bln of 2018 Sales, giving 8x Sales. This is extremely high but not extremely high in comparison to other “Winner-takes-all/Bubble stocks” which often trade on much higher multiples. Recent US IPOs Zoom Video Communications and PagerDuty, for instance, trade at 33x 2018 Sales and 27x Sales. In Europe, Adyen trades at 35x 2018 Sales. So 8x is not a stand-out necessarily and is a level from which the stock could even potentially (and perhaps counter-intuitively) rise substantially on fumes in the absence of new information. On the other hand, if there is no clear path to profitability then in due course, 8x Sales starts to seem like a lot. 2017 IPO Blue Apron (meal kits) being a case in point. The stock trades at 0.3x Sales having fallen 90% since the IPO.

BE11:56am

We view Uber's conservative pricing as a smart and prudent strategy coming out of the box as it clearly learned from its “little brother” Lyft, and the experience it has gone through over the past month. That said, we continue to view Lyft as a one trick pony domestic ride sharing player and believe Uber has clearly established itself as the clear #1 player in the ridesharing industry and is paving a similar road to what Amazon did to transform retail/ecommerce and Facebook did for social media. The brand loyalty of Uber is hard to dispute as the company continues to attract drivers and consumers illustrating an impressive formula to go after a $5.7 trillion opportunity globally on transportation which swells to $7-$8 trillion when including third-party food delivery and freight/logistics. A core tenet of our bull thesis on Uber is around the company’s ability to morph its unrivaled ridesharing platform into a broader consumer engine with Uber Eats, Uber Freight, and autonomous initiatives “just scratching the surface” of the full monetization potential of this platform over the next decade. From a valuation basis, we arrive at our $65 price target on Uber using Sum of the Parts valuation on 1) Ridesharing, 2) Uber Eats, 3) ATG/ Autonomous, and 4) Other Bets. We value Uber at $109 billion and believe the company has a slew of opportunities ahead of it in ridesharing, logistics, food delivery, and healthcare (e.g., hospitals and insurance providers) that make it a unique investment opportunity. We maintain our OUTPERFORM rating on Uber and continue to favor it over NEUTRAL-rated Lyft.

BE12:05pm

Following press reports earlier this morning, TKA has confirmed that it will abandon both its steel JV and business separation plans and rather propose an IPO of its Elevators business. Similar to what was noted in the planned APAM-VDM deal, the remedy assets required by the EC were too stringent, decreasing the value of planned synergies and ultimate economic benefits behind the deal. Over recent months, investors had notably soured on the JV over those fears. While mgmt had been adamant that a rights issue would not be required and the temporary crossshareholding between Materials and Industrials post separation would solidify the balance sheet, the fall in share price ultimately decreased the value of the crossshareholding.

BornCynic Thanks BE / JP / ROTR - enjoy the weekend
BE12:05pm

Elevators has been long held as the crown jewel in TKA's portfolio, contributing a significant portion of earnings (35% of FY19 total adjusted EBITDA) with more sustainable FCF generation. With peers Kone and Schindler trading at elevated multiples (c.14x 2020 cons EV/EBITDA ex-pension) there's significant value within the Elevators business which the conglomerate discount placed on TKA has historically masked. If TKA could IPO Elevators at those multiples, the enterprise value could be €14bn (100%-basis). Pension liabilities directly tied to Elevators are relatively limited (c.€325m on JEFe) and while net debt allocated to the division is not reported, there's clear and significant equity value that could help a TKA (ex-Elevators) reduce leverage (83% gearing on JEFe at FY19).

BE12:06pm

With the re-integration of Steel Europe as a continuing operation, TKA has increased FY19 adj EBIT from €1.0bn to €1.1-1.2bn. FCF before M&A is expected to be a high three-digit million negative figure with a net loss for the year. TKA will report full FQ2 earnings on Tuesday, 14 May. If Steel Europe is included as a continuing operation from FQ3 onwards, as indicated in the release, JEFe for FY19 continuing adj EBIT would be €1.2bn, the top end of guidance.

BE12:07pm

As we suggested recently (see here TKA - Confirms extensive remedy proposal), the extensive JV remedies required by the EC posed significant challenges in realising the planned €400m-500mn of synergies. We also note that: 1) the JV would still leave TKA with significant economic exposure to European steel for the years to come; and 2) the entity would have included Port Talbot (Tata Steel UK), which is arguably a weak asset amidst a tougher sector backdrop.
 In the hypothetical SOTP below, we add Steel back into the fold and assume the business split does not go ahead. In this scenario, and assuming a 15% conglomerate discount, we arrive at a fair value of ~€14.50/sh.

BE12:07pm

Assuming the Elevators carve-out is confirmed, we see three potential positives: 1) Elevators as a listed entity re-rates and TKA moves closer to fair value; 2) listing paves the way for re-assessment of potential deal with KONE new capital via a carve-out (e.g. listing of 10-20% stake would translate to ~€1.5-3bn cash inflow) would address the balance sheet concerns.
